'''Johnny Mars''' (born December 7, 1942)<ref name="AMG"/> is an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] harmonica player, singer, and songwriter. Over a long career, Mars has worked with [[Magic Sam]], [[Earl Hooker]], [[B.B. King]], [[Jesse Fuller]], [[Spencer Davis]], [[Ian Gillan]], [[Do-Re-Mi (band)|Do-Re-Mi]], [[Bananarama]] and [[Michael Roach (musician)|Michael Roach]].

==Biography==
####
Mars was born in [[Laurens, South Carolina]], [[United States]] to [[sharecropping]] parents.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p19170/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Johnny Mars |author=Richard Skelly |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=October 30, 2010}}</ref> His family regularly moved house when Mars was a youngster, but at the age of nine, he was presented with his first harmonica. When he was aged fourteen, and on the death of his mother, Mars and his younger siblings moved to [[New Paltz, New York]], and having left high school, Mars began playing in various [[nightclub|clubs]] in [[New York]].<ref name="Mars">{{cite web |url=http://www.johnnymars.com/biography.html |title=Johnny Mars biography |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Johnnymars.com |accessdate=October 30, 2011}}</ref>  He signed a [[recording contract]] with [[Mercury Records]] whilst a member of a band named Burning Bush, and they recorded several sides with the label.<ref name="AMG"/>

By the mid 1960s, Mars had moved to [[California]] and formed the Johnny Mars Band, who found work but no recognition beyond their North California base. However, they toured with [[Magic Sam]], and played on the same bill as [[Earl Hooker]], [[B.B. King]] and [[Jesse Fuller]].<ref name="Mars"/> After advice from Rick Estrin ([[Little Charlie & the Nightcats]]), Mars toured the [[United Kingdom]] in 1972, and subsequently recorded two albums there before fully relocating to [[Somerset]] in 1978.  Mars worked with the [[record producer]], [[Ray Fenwick]], plus [[Spencer Davis]] and [[Ian Gillan]].  His 1984 album, ''Life on Mars'', received critical acclaim.<ref name="AMG"/>

In 1988, Mars was a guest musician on the [[Do-Re-Mi (band)|Do-Re-Mi]] album, ''[[The Happiest Place in Town]]''. Mars later worked with [[Bananarama]] on "[[Preacher Man]]" (1990) and their 1991 [[cover version|cover]] of "[[Long Train Runnin'|Long Train Running]]", appearing in the group's [[music video]] for the former track.<ref name="AMG"/> Mars also taught for 15 years in primary schools in England, and worked with teenagers in music projects.<ref name="Mars"/> Mars continued touring across the UK and [[Europe]] where he had a strong fan base. In 1992, Mars played at the [[San Francisco Blues Festival]]. In 1999, Mars released ''Stateside'', and ''On My Mind'' followed in 2003.<ref name="AMG"/> In 2003 and 2004, Mars played with the The Barrelhouse Blues Orchestra.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.barrelhouse.org.uk/bbo.shtml |title=The Barrelhouse Blues Orchestra |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Barrelhouse.org.uk |accessdate=October 30, 2011}}</ref>

More recently, Mars teamed up with the blues guitarist, [[Michael Roach (musician)|Michael Roach]], and appeared at the Bath Music Festival (2008, UK),<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bathmusicfest.org.uk/billybragg.aspx |title=Billy Bragg + Michael Roach & Johnny Mars |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Bathmusicfest.org.uk |accessdate=October 30, 2011}}</ref> Pocono Blues Festival (US) and the Kastav Blues Festival (Croatia). In January 2010, the pair toured the Middle East.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.roachandmars.com/ |title=Michael Roach & Johnny Mars |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Roachandmars.com |accessdate=October 30, 2011}}</ref>
